Situation1: They attend a local workshop on updated prescription guidelines to ensure proper patient counseling.
Expectation2: Leading the daily prayers in the mosque
Situation2: A large gathering has assembled for a special remembrance, and no one else present is authorized to lead.
Story: I glanced at my watch as the workshop presenter discussed the latest prescription guidelines. My mind raced, absorbing every detail—this knowledge was crucial for my patients’ safety. Yet, as the clock ticked closer to Maghrib, my phone buzzed with a message from the mosque committee: a large crowd had gathered for a special remembrance, and I was the only authorized imam present. My heart pounded. The community expected me to lead the prayer, to offer guidance and comfort. But if I left now, I’d miss the most critical part of the workshop, risking my professional responsibility to stay updated and provide the best care. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing on my chest. The pharmacist in me knew the importance of this training, while the imam in me couldn’t ignore the spiritual needs of my congregation. I stared at the exit, wrestling with the impossible choice, feeling the expectations of two worlds pulling me in opposite directions.
